image.altText: Anne Pedler with two young boys.

items.synopsis: A coroner blasts a Tasmanian hospital over the death of a woman, noting her illness was "underestimated in the extreme" and that she spent eight hours in an ambulance outside the facility as "no bed [was] available for her" due to a "lack of nursing staff on duty".

title.children: 'There was no-one there for her': Daughter mourns mum as coroner lashes hospital where 71yo died while ramped

image.altText: An out of focus man and woman walk past a building with glass sliding doors and a sign reading Reserve Bank of Australia.

items.synopsis: The Reserve Bank leaves interest rates on hold for the second month in a row, raising questions about whether it may be finished hiking borrowing costs.

title.children: RBA leaves interest rates on hold for second consecutive month

image.altText: Charlie Read looks at the camera.

items.synopsis: The son of one of Australia's most notorious criminals pleads not guilty to drugs, stealing and gun charges over an arrest in Hobart earlier this year.

title.children: Son of Chopper pleads not guilty to gun, drug offences after road spike arrest

image.altText: A horse tethered to harness gear.

items.synopsis: A series of emails obtained by the ABC show the head of Tasmania's racing authority was concerned allegations about a prominent harness racing trainer were about to "go nuclear" in the weeks before an ABC investigation aired.

title.children: 'This is going to go nuclear': Emails reveal racing head's fears amid ABC investigation

image.altText: Targa Tasmania competitors with black tape over one headlight.

items.synopsis: Targa Australia rejects claims it is ignoring attempts to improve race safety by proceeding with next year's Tasmanian event, saying if Motor Sports Australia releases recommendations in time, it will try to implement them.

title.children: Chasing 'plates not points' will reinvigorate Targa Tasmania, say organisers

image.altText: Philip Lowe wearing glasses and a suit sits at a table and speaks.

items.synopsis: The RBA has left interest rates on hold at 4.1 per cent. It leaves the cash rate at its highest level since April 2012. Follow live.

title.children: RBA warns another rate hike may be on the cards despite holding off in August

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Some of the big banks have wasted no time in changing their forecasts off the back of the RBA leaving rates on hold today. NAB is now expecting the RBA's terminal cash rate target will be 4.35%, and has pencilled in a final hike in November. Before today, NAB was expecting a 4.6% peak. Commonwealth Bank has also revised its projections for the cash rate based on the RBA's decision. The nation's biggest lender now expects that the cash rate will remain on hold at 4.1% for an extended period.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Major banks are already changing their minds on the peak RBA cash rate

children.content: Some of the big banks have wasted no time in changing their forecasts off the back of the RBA leaving rates on hold today.
NAB is now expecting the RBA's terminal cash rate target will be 4.35%, and has
pencilled in a final hike in November
Before today, NAB was expecting a 4.6% peak.
Commonwealth Bank
has also revised its projections for the cash rate based on the RBA's decision.
The nation's biggest lender now expects that the cash rate will
remain on hold at 4.1%
for an extended period.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: China's economy is slowing down and Beijing has announced a raft of targeted stimulus measures to boost growth, although there's been no sign yet of the big cash splashes of the past. But Rio boss Jakob Stausholm has told Kirsten Aiken on The Business that he is 'cautiously optimistic' about China. And he's hopeful that Beijing's pledge for more sugar hits will come through. "I'm very encouraged by hearing that the government in China acknowledge that they are opportunities to strengthen the economy." " And experience tells us that when they acknowledge that there is an issue, that they know exactly how to address the issue." "We don't know what the measures are." "We don't know how much measures, but I remain cautiously optimistic." The big miner saw net profit for the half year slump by 43 per cent to $US5.1 billion ($7.5 billion) as commodity prices fell, and after it took a big write down on its aluminium business. You can see more of that interview tonight on The Business at 8:45pm on the ABC News Channel and on Iview.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rio Tinto boss 'cautiously optimistic' about China

children.content: China's economy is slowing down and Beijing has announced a raft of targeted stimulus measures to boost growth, although there's been no sign yet of the big cash splashes of the past.
But Rio boss Jakob Stausholm has told Kirsten Aiken on The Business that he is 'cautiously optimistic' about China.
And he's hopeful that Beijing's pledge for more sugar hits will come through.
"I'm very encouraged by hearing that the government in China acknowledge that they are opportunities to strengthen the economy."
" And experience tells us that when they acknowledge that there is an issue, that they know exactly how to address the issue."
"We don't know what the measures are."
"We don't know how much measures, but I remain cautiously optimistic."
The big miner saw net profit for the half year slump by 43 per cent to $US5.1 billion ($7.5 billion) as commodity prices fell, and after it took a big write down on its aluminium business.
You can see more of that interview tonight on The Business at 8:45pm on the ABC News Channel and on Iview.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian investors liked the news that the Reserve Bank was keeping interest rates on hold at 4.1 per cent, an 11 year high. The ASX 200 index put on 0.5 per cent with technology, industrial and consumer firms doing the best because they benefit from lower interest rates. Energy stocks, miners and banks were among the gainers. The only sector that fell today were education stocks. And the Australian dollar tumbled by 1 per cent to 66.56 US cents because the cost of borrowing did not go up. Investors think that the RBA could be done with its rate hiking cycle. TPG Telecom (+11.6 per cent) was the best performer, while Credit Corp (-12.6 per cent) did the worst.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX ends higher as RBA pauses rate hikes

children.content: Australian investors liked the news that the Reserve Bank was keeping interest rates on hold at 4.1 per cent, an 11 year high.
The ASX 200 index put on 0.5 per cent with technology, industrial and consumer firms doing the best because they benefit from lower interest rates.
Energy stocks, miners and banks were among the gainers.
The only sector that fell today were education stocks.
And the Australian dollar tumbled by 1 per cent to 66.56 US cents because the cost of borrowing did not go up.
Investors think that the RBA could be done with its rate hiking cycle.
TPG Telecom (+11.6 per cent) was the best performer, while Credit Corp (-12.6 per cent) did the worst.

props.alt: Best and worst performers on ASX 200

children.content: ASX movers
(Refinitiv)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: This is a training exercise now. Roord volleys in from close range after some super work by Janssen down the left, leaving about four defenders in her wake.

children.content: This is a training exercise now.
Roord volleys in from close range after some super work by Janssen down the left, leaving about four defenders in her wake.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: What a strike from Brugts, who strolls forward and curls it into the top corner from outside the box. The consequence of this rout is that the US might not actually top the group, even if they beat Portugal - with the Dutch boosting their goal difference.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 18' That's 3-0 to the Dutch

children.content: What a strike from Brugts, who strolls forward and curls it into the top corner from outside the box.
The consequence of this rout is that the US might not actually top the group, even if they beat Portugal - with the Dutch boosting their goal difference.
